item.title: When It Comes to Russia, Trump Navigates Conflicting Goals
item.description: President Trump’s efforts to court President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia are rife with contradictions about stability and displays of American power.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin in Alaska last August. Mr. Trump’s focus on strength has magnified tensions with Russia in regions like Latin America, where Mr. Putin has sought to extend his influence

item.title: Steny Hoyer, Longest-Serving House Democrat, to Retire From Congress
item.description: The Maryland congressman, who served as one of his party’s top leaders, plans to depart after nearly half a century in Congress, as his party looks toward generational change.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Steny Hoyer in October.

item.title: What We Know About the Fatal ICE Shooting in Minneapolis
item.description: Officials in Minnesota have disputed federal accounts of the shooting that killed a 37-year-old woman on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri and Hannah Ziegler
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: A vigil last night in Minneapolis on the street where Renee Nicole Good was killed after an encounter with federal officers on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Withdraws the U.S. From More International Organizations
item.description: The executive order the president signed Wednesday follows a broader vision of American foreign policy that shuns coalition building and the consensus of nations.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump speaking at the United Nations General Assembly last year. The U.N. did not immediately comment on the United States’ severing relationships with some of its organizations.

item.title: Trump Proposes Huge Increase in Military Spending
item.description: The president’s proposal for a $600 billion increase comes as his administration pushes for American imperialism.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Military vehicles moving across the Arlington Memorial Bridge during a military parade in Washington in June.

item.title: How Venezuela Is Already Rattling Republican Thomas Massie’s Primary Race
item.description: Most Republicans are on board with Trump’s aggression. Not Thomas Massie.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times; Jeff Faughender/Courier Journal, via Imagn
item.media:description: Representative Thomas Massie of Kentucky, left, is facing a Trump-backed challenge from Ed Gallrein, right.

item.title: During Maduro Raid in Venezuela, a Close Call for Helicopters and Trump’s Plan
item.description: As a damaged U.S. helicopter struggled to stay aloft over Venezuela’s capital, the success of the entire operation hung in the balance.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Greg Jaffe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Trump’s Claim to Venezuelan Oil Money Draws Scrutiny in Congress
item.description: Democrats say the president cannot take money from the proceeds of seized oil and control it himself, calling it a ‘slush fund’ that would fly in the face of the Constitution.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Democratic Senators Chris Murphy of Connecticut, left, and Chris Van Hollen of Maryland criticized President Trump’s declaration that he will control the proceeds from oil produced in Venezuela.

item.title: Lawmakers Split After Classified Briefings on Venezuela
item.description: Republicans praised what they characterized as a narrow and well-executed plan, while Democrats expressed alarm, warning that the mission was vaguely defined.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison and Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio speaking at the Capitol on Wednesday after a Senate briefing on operations in Venezuela.

item.title: Rubio Lays Out Long-Term U.S. Involvement in Venezuela
item.description: The secretary of state told lawmakers the administration has a three-phase plan for Venezuela after ousting its leader, including seizing oil and controlling the proceeds.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio told reporters that the first priority would be “the stabilization of the country.”

item.title: How The Times Is Drawing on Over a Century of Reporting in Venezuela
item.description: The New York Times has been on the ground in the country since at least the 1880s, through celebration, suffering and political turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario/Corbis Saba, for The New York Times
item.media:description: The New York Times has made on-the-ground reporting in Venezuela a priority for more than a century. Above, a demonstration against Hugo Chávez in 2002.

item.title: Trump Deepens Scrutiny of Minnesota, a Potential Model for Other Blue States
item.description: The White House is intensifying and broadening its probes into fraud in states led by prominent Democrats.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents executed a search warrant as part of a fraud investigation in Bloomington, Minn., last month.

item.title: Trump officials threaten to expand a crackdown on fraud in Minnesota to other Democratic-run states.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Homan, President Trump’s border czar, speaking with Kristi Noem, the secretary of homeland security, outside the White House last year. Both have indicated that investigations into fraud in public would widen to include more states.

item.title: California Tech Executives Plot Against Rep. Ro Khanna Over Support of Wealth Tax
item.description: It’s hard right now to be a progressive Democrat in the heart of America’s tech industry.
item.dc:creator: Theodore Schleifer
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Ro Khanna of California has publicly defended a proposed ballot measure for a wealth tax in California that has angered some of the state’s richest executives.

item.title: New Dietary Guidelines Abandon Longstanding Advice on Alcohol
item.description: Now the government’s recommendation is to “limit” drinking, without specifying safe amounts for men and women. The guidelines no longer warn of risks like cancer.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: New guidelines issued on Wednesday say that people should consume less alcohol “for better overall health” and “limit alcohol beverages,” but they don’t recommend clear limits.

item.title: Oil Firms Say Venezuela Owes Them Billions Over Earlier Investments
item.description: Companies like Exxon Mobil and ConocoPhillips say that Venezuela owes them billions of dollars for confiscating their assets two decades ago.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A tanker docked near a refinery in Punto Fijo, Venezuela. The cost of restoring the country’s oil production after decades of decline is expected to be substantial.

item.title: After Maduro Ouster, Trump’s Venezuela Moves Pose a Challenge for GOP in Congress
item.description: Republicans have cheered the raid that ousted Nicolás Maduro but toiled to square their longstanding views with President Trump’s unclear and rapidly evolving strategy.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We do not have U.S. armed forces in Venezuela, and we are not occupying that country,” Speaker Mike Johnson said on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Seizes Oil Tanker and Boards Another Amid Tensions With Russia
item.description: The first ship had eluded the Coast Guard after being stopped on its way to pick up oil in Venezuela. U.S. forces also boarded another tanker in international waters near the Caribbean.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas, Eric Schmitt, Julian E. Barnes and Christiaan Triebert
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: As Charlie Kirk’s Turning Point Pushes Into High Schools, Dissension Follows
item.description: Since Mr. Kirk’s death, chapters of his organization’s affiliate for teenagers have more than doubled in number, aided by politicians who have said they won’t tolerate opposition.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.media:credit: Lexi Parra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Club America members from Stratford High School in Houston found themselves caught between concerned parents on the left and Texas’ most powerful politicians on the right.

item.title: U.S. Details Plan for Venezuela’s Oil Sales After Trump Claims Millions of Barrels
item.description: The Trump administration said it had an agreement with Venezuela’s government, but the country’s state-owned oil company said negotiations were underway.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott and Robert Jimison
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil refinery in Punto Fijo, Venezuela. President Trump said late Tuesday that Venezuela would soon send 30 million to 50 million barrels of oil to the United States.

item.title: U.S. Appeals Court Won’t Take Up Case to Resurrect 9/11 Plea Deal
item.description: The decision removes a chance for the defendants to resolve the long-running case with the death penalty taken off the table. Instead, pretrial hearings are likely to resume.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The decision by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit most likely means pretrial hearings in the case will resume before the 25th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

item.title: Fed’s Independence Faces Critical Tests as Trump Seeks to Remake Institution
item.description: The central bank faces two major hurdles early on in 2026 that will determine the extent to which it operates free of political meddling.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has said anybody who disagrees with him will never get the top job at the Federal Reserve, prompting concern that his nominee will prioritize pleasing him over all else.
